chapter.title: Keeping LD information confidential
chapter.content:
Keeping LD information confidential

Our third Guiding question asks:

How can information about LD be kept confidential?

This question shifts our focus from the responsibilities of individuals with LD to the responsibilities of the service provider. Let’s talk about confidentiality and what it means when working with adults with suspected LD.

chapter.title: Questions that invite self-disclosure
chapter.content:
Questions that invite self-disclosure

As we mentioned earlier, it is not appropriate to target an individual and directly ask if he or she has a disability. This is the foundational rule of confidentiality.

It is, however, okay to ask questions around an individual’s experiences that will invite self-disclosure. Some examples include:

  • “In school, what were your favorite and least favorite subjects?”
  • “Describe your areas of strength and areas you would like to improve.”
  • “In the past, what made learning a challenge?”

It is also acceptable to ‘generally’ invite disclosure to groups of students – at intake, or at other points in the instructional process.

For example, at a program orientation session prior to initial assessment a counselor or teacher might say: “If you suspect or know you have a condition that may require accommodations, or adjustments to assessment or instruction, please let myself or someone on staff know.”

chapter.title: Broken confidentiality could violate the Rehab Act or ADAAA
chapter.content:
Broken confidentiality could violate the Rehab Act or ADAAA

Once an individual has disclosed a disability, the educational institution or workplace is responsible for keeping that individual’s disability confidential, and may not release any part of the documentation without the person’s informed and written consent.

If confidentiality is broken, this could result in a violation of an individual’s rights under the Rehab Act or ADAAA.

chapter.title: Suggested confidentiality procedures
chapter.content:
Suggested confidentiality procedures

Some suggested procedures for maintaining confidentiality of an individual’s disability information include:

  • providing  written consent forms at intake, or before releasing information;
  • keeping information about the disability in a secure location, where permission is required for access;
  • providing program staff with information and training regarding confidentiality guidelines; and
  • routinely reviewing if you, or your program is following confidentiality procedures appropriately.
